{{about|the preservation of cultural heritage|cultural heritage as a concept|Cultural heritage|vocation and practice of managing cultural heritage|Cultural heritage management}} [[File:Penn Station2.jpg|thumb|[[Demolition]] of the former [[Pennsylvania Station (1910–1963)|Penn Station]] concourse raised public awareness about preservation]] '''Historic preservation''' (US), '''heritage preservation''' or '''heritage conservation''' (UK), is an endeavour that seeks to preserve, conserve and protect buildings, objects, landscapes or other artifacts of historical significance. This term refers specifically to the preservation of the built environment, and not to preservation of, for example, primeval forests or wilderness.Maryland Association of Historic District Commissions, ''[http://www.mahdc.org/index.php/library-of-resources Handbook] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110727055105/http://www.mahdc.org/index.php/library-of-resources |date=2011-07-27 }}'' (1997). ==History== ===England=== In [[England]], [[Antiquary|antiquarian]] interests were a familiar gentleman's pursuit since the mid 17th century, developing in tandem with the rise in scientific curiosity. Fellows of the [[Royal Society]] were often also Fellows of the [[Society of Antiquaries of London|Society of Antiquaries]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}}. [[File:Castle Berkhamsted cz.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of Berkhamsted from the Norman Castle's Motte|The ruins of Berkhamsted castle (viewed from its Norman motte) and Berkhamsted Common were the location of two successful early preservation events in the nineteenth century. (Enlarged: A train passes Berkhamsted castle, on an embankment that was once part of the castle's outer defences.)]]Many historic sites were damaged as the railways began to spread across the UK; including [[Trinity College Kirk|Trinity Hospital]] and its church in Edinburgh, [[Furness Abbey]], [[Berwick Castle|Berwick]] and [[Northampton Castle]], and the ancient walls of York, Chester and Newcastle. In 1833 [[Berkhamsted Castle]] became the first historic site in England officially protected by statute under the London and Birmingham Railway Acts of 1833{{ndash}}1837, though the new railway line in 1834 did demolish the castle's gatehouse and outer earthworks to the south.{{cite book|author=Michael Wheeler|title=Ruskin and Environment: The Storm-cloud of the Nineteenth Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pNxRAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA125|date=1 January 1995|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=978-0-7190-4377-2|pages=125–}} Another early preservation event also occurred at [[Berkhamsted]]. In 1866, Lord Brownlow who lived at [[Ashridge]], tried to enclose the adjoining Berkhamsted Common with {{convert|5|ft|m|0|adj=on}} steel fences in an attempt to claim it as part of his estate. In England from early Anglo-Saxon times, [[Common land]] was an area of land which the local community could use as a resource. Across England between 1660 and 1845, 7 million acres of Common land had been [[enclosure|enclosed]] by private land owners by application to parliament. On the night of 6 March 1866, [[Augustus Smith (politician)|Augustus Smith]] MP led gangs of local folk and hired men from London's East End in [[direct action]] to break the enclosure fences and protect Berkhamsted Common for the people of Berkhamsted in what became known nationally as the Battle of Berkhamsted Common.{{harvnb|Cobb|1883|p=26}}.{{harvnb|Sherwood|2008|p=245}}.{{harvnb|Birtchnell|1988|ps=none}}. In 1870, [[Robert Hunter (National Trust)|Sir Robert Hunter]] (later co-founder of the [[National Trust]] in 1895) and the [[Commons Preservation Society]] succeed in legal action that ensured protection of Berkhamsted Common and other open spaces threatened with enclosure. In 1926 the common was acquired by the National Trust.{{cite news|title=Mr. Shaw-Lefevre on the Preservation of Commons|newspaper=The Times|date=11 December 1886|page=10}}{{cite web|last=Ashbrook |first=Kate |url=http://commons.ncl.ac.uk/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Kate-Ashbrook.pdf|title=Modern commons: a protected open space?|accessdate=24 October 2014}}{{cite web | url=http://www.hemeltoday.co.uk/news/more-news/exhibition-and-commemorative-walk-marks-anniversary-of-battle-to-save-berkhamsted-common-1-7006636 | title=Exhibition and commemorative walk marks anniversary of battle to save Berkhamsted Common | publisher=Johnston Publishing Ltd. | work=Hemel Gazette | date=12 October 2015 | accessdate=14 October 2015}} [[File:John Lubbock72.jpg|thumb|right|200x200px|[[John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury|John Lubbock]], MP was a moving force behind the implementation of the Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1882.]]By the mid 19th century, much of [[UK|Britain's]] unprotected cultural heritage was being slowly destroyed. Even well-meaning archaeologists like [[William Greenwell]] excavated sites with virtually no attempt at their preservation, [[Stonehenge]] came under increasing threat by the 1870s. Tourists were chipping off parts of the stones or carving their initials into the rock. The private owners of the monument decided to sell the land to the [[London and South-Western Railway]] as the monument was "not the slightest use to anyone now"{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}}. [[John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury|John Lubbock]], an MP and botanist emerged as the champion of the country's national heritage. In 1872 he personally bought private land that housed ancient monuments in [[Avebury]], [[Silbury Hill]] and elsewhere, from the owners who were threatening to have them cleared away to make room for housing. Soon, he began campaigning in Parliament for legislation to protect monuments from destruction. This finally led to the legislative milestone under the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] government of [[William Gladstone]] of the [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1882]]. The first government appointed inspector for this job was the archaeologist [[Augustus Pitt-Rivers]]. This legislation was regarded by conservative political elements as a grave assault on the individual rights of property of the owner, and consequently, the inspector only had the power to identify endangered landmarks and offer to purchase them from the owner with his consent. The Act only covered ancient monuments and explicitly did not cover historic buildings or structures. In 1877 the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]] was founded by the [[Arts and Crafts]] designer [[William Morris]] to prevent the destruction of historic buildings, followed by the [[National Trust]] in 1895 that bought estates from their owners for preservation.Bryson, Bill. "At Home: A Short History of Private Life" Transworld Publishers, 2010 The [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1882]] had only given legal protection to prehistoric sites, such as ancient [[tumulus|tumuli]]. The [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1900]] took this further by empowering the government's Commissioners of Work and local County Councils to protect a wider range of properties. Further updates were made in [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1910|1910]]. [[File:Tattershall Castle, 2006.jpg|left|200px|upright|thumbnail|[[Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire|Tattershall Castle]], preserved at personal expense by [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|Lord Curzon]] and a catalyst for [[Ancient Monuments Consolidation and Amendment Act 1913|broader heritage protection laws]].]] [[Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire|Tattershall Castle]], [[Lincolnshire]], a medieval [[manor house]] had been put up for sale in 1910 with its greatest treasures, the huge medieval fireplaces, still intact. However, when an American bought the house they were ripped out and packaged up for shipping. The former viceroy of [[India]], [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston]], was outraged at this cultural destruction and stepped in to buy back the castle and reinstall the fireplaces. After a nationwide hunt for them they were finally found in London and returned.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-21587468|title=The man who demolished Shakespeare's house|publisher=BBC News Magazine|author=Denise Winterman}} He restored the castle{{cite book|title=English Castles: A Guide by Counties|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|author=Adrian Pettifer|pages=145–7|year=2002}} and left it to the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] on his death in 1925. His experience at Tattershall influenced Lord Curzon to push for tougher heritage protection laws in Britain, which saw passage as the [[Ancient Monuments Consolidation and Amendment Act 1913]]. The new structure involved the creation of the Ancient Monuments Board to oversee the protection of such monuments. Powers were given for the board, with Parliamentary approval, to issue preservation orders to protect monuments, and extended the public right of access to these. The term "monument" was extended to include the lands around it, allowing the protection of the wider landscape.Mynors, p.9. ====The National Trust==== {{one source section|date=October 2017}} The [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] was founded in 1894 by [[Octavia Hill]], [[Robert Hunter (National Trust)|Sir Robert Hunter]], and [[Hardwicke Rawnsley|Hardwicke Canon Rawnsley]] as the first organisation of its type in the world. Its formal purpose is:
The preservation for the benefit of the Nation of lands and [[Tenement (law)|tenements]] (including buildings) of beauty or historic interest and, as regards lands, for the preservation of their natural aspect, features and animal and plant life. Also the preservation of furniture, pictures and chattels of any description having national and historic or artistic interest.{{cite web | url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/documents/download-national-trust-acts-1907-1971-post-order-2005.pdf | title=The National Trust Acts 1907 - 1971, as varied by a Parliamentary Scheme implemented by The Charities (National Trust) Order 2005 | publisher=[[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] | accessdate=10 November 2017 | pages=4}}
In the early days, the Trust was concerned primarily with protecting open spaces and a variety of threatened buildings; its first property was [[Alfriston Clergy House]] and its first [[nature reserve]] was [[Wicken Fen]]. Its first archaeological monument was [[White Barrow]]. The focus on [[English country house|country houses]] and gardens, which now comprise the majority of its most visited properties, came about in the mid 20th century, when it was realised that the private owners of many of these properties were no longer able to afford to maintain them. The Town and Country Planning Act 1944 and the [[Town and Country Planning Act 1990]] took steps toward historic preservation on an unprecedented scale.{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} Concern about the demolition of historic buildings arose in institutions such as the pressure group [[the Society for the Preservation of Historic Buildings]], which appealed against demolition and neglect on a case by case basis.{{cite web|url=http://www.sphb.org.uk |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821104238/http://www.sphb.org.uk/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-08-21 |title=The Society for the Preservation of Historic Buildings (SPHB)|publisher=sphb.org.uk|accessdate=2012-10-29}} ====English Heritage==== [[English Heritage]] formed in 1983, is a registered charity that looks after the National Heritage Collection in England.{{cite web|title=New Era for English Heritage|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/about-us/search-news/new-era-for-englands-heritage1|website=English Heritage|publisher=English Heritage Trust|accessdate=6 April 2015}} This comprises over 400 of England's historic buildings, monuments and sites spanning more than 5,000 years of history. Within its portfolio are [[Stonehenge]], [[Dover Castle]], [[Tintagel Castle]] and the best preserved parts of [[Hadrian's Wall]]. Originally English Heritage was the operating name of an executive [[non-departmental public body]] of the [[Her Majesty's Government|British Government]], officially titled the [[Historic Buildings and Monuments Commission for England]], that ran the national system of heritage protection and managed a range of historic properties.{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/about-us/our-history/|website=English Heritage|publisher=English Heritage Trust|accessdate=6 April 2015}} It was created to combine the roles of existing bodies that had emerged from a long period of state involvement in heritage protection. In 1999 the organisation merged with the [[Royal Commission on the Historical Monuments of England]] and the National Monuments Record (England), bringing together resources for the identification and survey of England's historic environment. On 1 April 2015, English Heritage was divided into two parts: [[Historic England]], which inherited the statutory and protection functions of the old organisation, and the new [[English Heritage Trust]], a charity that would operate the historic properties, and which took on the English Heritage operating name and logo.{{cite news|last1=Lean|first1=Geoffrey|title=Does our history have a future in the hands of the English Heritage Trust?|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/earth/environment/conservation/11441254/Does-our-history-have-a-future-in-the-hands-of-the-English-Heritage-Trust.html|accessdate=6 April 2015|work=The Telegraph|date=28 February 2015}} The British government gave the new charity an £80 million grant to help establish it as an independent trust, although the historic properties remained in the ownership of the state. ===United States=== {{see also|National Park Service|Antiquities Act}} [[File:MountVernonrear.jpg|thumb|right|
[[Mount Vernon]] [[plantations in the American South|plantation]], near [[Alexandria, Virginia]]
]] In the United States one of the first historic preservation efforts was the [[Washington's Headquarters State Historic Site]], in [[Newburgh, New York]]. This property has the distinction of being the first-ever property designated and operated as a historic site by a U.S. state, having been so since 1850. Another early historic preservation undertaking was that of George Washington's [[Mount Vernon]] in 1858.Lea, Diane. "America's Preservation Ethos: A Tribute to Enduring Ideals." ''A Richer Heritage: Historic Preservation in the Twenty-First Century.'' ed. Robert Stipe. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2003. p.2 Founded in 1889, the Richmond, Virginia-based [[Preservation Virginia]] (formerly known as the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities) was the United States' first statewide historic preservation group.{{cite web |author=Helium Studio |url=http://apva.org/aboutus/ |title=Preservation Virginia |publisher=Apva.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008020715/http://www.apva.org/AboutUs/ |archivedate=2012-10-08 |df= }}Lindgren, James Michael. ''Preserving the Old Dominion: historic preservation and Virginia traditionalism''. Charlottesville: University Press of Virginia, 1993. 3. Print. The [[American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society]] was formed in 1895 as the first American organization of its kind in the United States that did not limit its activities to a single historic place or object. The Society operated as a national organization to: protect the natural scenery and the preservation of historic landmarks; to preserve landmarks and records of the past or present; to erect memorials and promote appreciation of the scenic beauty of America."Scenic and Historic America: Bulletin of the American Scenic and Historic Preservation Society." ASHPS 2.1 (March 1930):3. [[Charles E. Peterson]] was an influential figure in the mid-20th century establishing the [[Historic American Buildings Survey]] (HABS), advising on the establishment of [[Independence National Historical Park]], helping with the first graduate degree program in historic preservation in the United States at [[Columbia University]], and author. The architectural firm of Simons & Lapham (Albert Simons and [[Samuel Lapham VI|Samuel Lapham]]) was an influential supporter of the nation's first historic preservation ordinance in [[Charleston, South Carolina]] in 1930, affording that city a regulatory means by which to prevent the destruction of its historic building stock. In 1925, efforts to preserve the historic buildings of the [[French Quarter]] in [[New Orleans]] led to the creation of the Vieux Carré Commission and later, to the adoption of a historic preservation ordinance.Blevins, ''Documentation of the Architecture of the Architecture of Samuel Lapham and the Firm of Simons & Lapham'', Masters of Fine Arts in Historic Preservation Thesis, Savannah College of Art & Design, 2001Ellis, Scott S. (2010). Madame Vieux Carré: the French Quarter in the Twentieth Century. University of Mississippi. p. 43. [[File:1601 14th Street NW montage.jpg|thumb|left|350px|The preservation of this historic building in Washington, D.C. resulted in an award for Excellence in Historic Preservation by the local government.{{cite web |url=http://dgs.dc.gov/release/dgs-mayor-gray-announces-winners-historic-preservation-awards |title=Mayor Gray Announces Winners of Historic Preservation Awards |publisher=Government of the District of Columbia |accessdate=October 22, 2014 }}]] The US [[National Trust for Historic Preservation]], another privately funded [[non-profit organization]], began in 1949 with a handful of structures and has developed goals that provide "leadership, education, advocacy, and resources to save America's diverse historic places and revitalize our communities" according to the Trust's mission statement. In 1951 the Trust assumed responsibility for its first museum property, [[Woodlawn Plantation]] in [[northern Virginia]]. Twenty-eight sites in all have subsequently become part of the National Trust, representing the [[cultural diversity]] of American history. In New York City, the destruction of [[Pennsylvania Station (1910–1963)|Pennsylvania Station]] in 1964 shocked many nationwide into supporting preservation. The 1960s proved advantageous with new laws and international agreements extending preservation "from ancient monuments to whole districts and buildings a few decades old."{{Cite journal|last=Abramson|first=Daniel|year=2012|title=From Obsolescence to Sustainability, Back Again, and Beyond|url=|journal=Design and Culture|volume=4|issue=3|pages=279–298|via=}} On an international level, the New York-based [[World Monuments Fund]] was founded in 1965 to preserve historic sites all over the world. Under the direction of [[James Marston Fitch]], the first advanced-degree historic preservation program began at [[Columbia University]] in 1964.Murtagh, William J. ''Keeping Time: The History and Theory of Preservation in America''. New York: Sterling Publishing, Co., 1997. It became the model on which most other graduate historic preservation programs were created.Michael Tomlan. "Historic Preservation Education: Alongside Architecture in Academia." ''Journal of Architectural Education'', Vol. 47, No. 4. (1994): 187-196. Many other programs were to follow before 1980: M.A. in Preservation Planning from Cornell (1975); M.S. in Historic Preservation from [[University of Vermont|the University of Vermont]] (1975); M.S. in Historic Preservation Studies from [[Boston University]] (1976); M.S. in Historic Preservation from [[Eastern Michigan University]] (1979) and M.F.A. in Historic Preservation was one of the original programs at [[Savannah College of Art & Design]]. James Marston Fitch also offered guidance and support towards the founding of the Master of Preservation Studies Degree within the Tulane School of Architecture{{cite web|url=http://architecture.tulane.edu|title=Tulane School of Architecture -|website=architecture.tulane.edu}} in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://architecture.tulane.edu/programs/degrees/mps-master-preservation-studies|title=Master of Preservation Studies|website=Tulane School of Architecture}} The M.Sc. in Building Conservation degree program is offered by the School of Architecture at [[Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute]] in Troy, New York. In 2005, Clemson University and the College of Charleston created an M.S. degree program based in Charleston, SC. The first undergraduate programs (B.A.) appeared in 1977 from [[Goucher College]] and [[Roger Williams University]] (then called Roger Williams College), followed by [[Mary Washington College]] in 1979.''Preservation News'' (Oct 1, 1979) {{As of|2013}} there were more than fifty historic preservation programs offering certificates, associate, bachelor's, and master's degrees in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.ncpe.us/academic-programs/#.UqsZqvSry-M|title=Home Page|date=13 September 2015|publisher=}} ===Canada=== {{Main|Heritage conservation in Canada}} In [[Canada]], the phrase "heritage preservation" is sometimes seen as a specific approach to the treatment of historic places and sites, rather than a general concept of conservation. "Conservation" is taken as the more general term, referring to all actions or processes that are aimed at safeguarding the character-defining elements of a cultural resource so as to retain its heritage value and extend its physical life. Historic objects in Canada may be granted special designation by any of the three levels of government: the [[Government of Canada|central government]], the [[Provinces and territories of Canada|provincial governments]], or a [[local government in Canada|municipal government]]. The [[Heritage Canada Foundation]] acts as Canada's lead advocacy organisation for heritage buildings and landscapes. === The Netherlands === [[Victor de Stuers]] is widely considered the man who started historic preservation in the Netherlands. In 1875 the first national department for conservation was established{{Cite web|url=http://arthistorians.info/stuersv|title=Dictionary of Art Historians|website=arthistorians.info|access-date=2017-11-08}} and de Stuers was appointed as the first legal secretary at the Ministry of Home Affairs as chief of the brand new Department of Arts and Sciences. He was the driving force behind ''[[Monumentenzorg]]'' (Foundation for Historic Preservation), helped found the ''[[Rijksmuseum]]'' (National Museum) and the ''Rijksarchief'' (National Archives).{{Cite web|url=http://www.kerkindenhaag.nl/agendaberichten/victor-de-stuers-vader-van-monumentenzorg-en-rijksmuseum/|title=Victor de Stuers, vader van Monumentenzorg en Rijksmuseum - Kerk in Den Haag|website=www.kerkindenhaag.nl|language=nl|access-date=2017-11-08}}{{Cite web|url=http://resources.huygens.knaw.nl/bwn1880-2000/lemmata/bwn1/stuers|title=Stuers, jhr. Victor Eugène Louis de (1843-1916)|last=Lunsingh Scheurleer|first=Th. H.|date=12 November 2013|website=|access-date=}} However, it was not until the 20th century that there was national legislation on historic preservation. In 1961 the [[:nl:Monumentenwet|''Monumentenwet'']] (“Monuments Act”) was passed. It defined that any physical building or space that was at least fifty years old and “which are of general interest because of their beauty, their meaning to science or their social value” and must thus be preserved.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/till014sche01_01/till014sche01_01_0031.php|title=J.A.C. Tillema, Schetsen uit de geschiedenis van de monumentenzorg in Nederland · dbnl|last=DBNL|website=DBNL|language=nl|access-date=2017-11-08}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=X9mhXFqd2DcC&pg=PA51&lpg=PA51&dq=monumentenwet+1961&source=bl&ots=yY2eFRfuPj&sig=rAJV5AXXGnlTKsPcmxLcmMPY4vI&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjrruD1h67XAhWEl5QKHZP_CjsQ6AEIQzAE#v=onepage&q=monumentenwet%201961&f=false|title=European Heritage, Planning and Management|last=Howard|first=Peter|last2=Ashworth|first2=Gregory John|date=1999|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=9781841500058|language=en}} In 1988 this Act was replaced by the ''[[:nl:Monumentenwet 1988|Monumentenwet 1988]]'' (“Monuments Act 1988”){{Cite web|url=http://wetten.overheid.nl/BWBR0004471/2016-04-14|title=wetten.nl - Regeling - Monumentenwet 1988 - BWBR0004471|website=wetten.overheid.nl|language=nl|access-date=2017-11-08}} and in 2015 by the ''[[:nl:Erfgoedwet|Erfgoedwet]]'' (“Heritage Law”).{{Cite news|url=https://cultureelerfgoed.nl/dossiers/erfgoedwet|title=Erfgoedwet|date=2014-08-25|work=Rijksdienst voor het Cultureel Erfgoed|access-date=2017-11-08|language=nl}} In 1973, the NGO ''Monumentenwacht'' (“Monument Watch”) was founded with the purpose of providing preventative measures of maintenance for historic buildings. As the majority of the historic preservation programs in the Netherlands, this program is decentralized, managed on the provincial level.{{cite web|url=http://www.wcmt.org.uk/sites/default/files/migrated-reports/629_1.pdf|title=Devlin, H. (2005). European initiatives in preventative maintenance for historic buildings. Retrieved from www.wcmt.org.uk|publisher=}} Owners of heritage buildings can subscribe to the services of Monumentenwacht and receive regular visits for inspection. The costs are covered through a combination of national and provincial subsidies.{{Cite journal |last=Weaver |first=Martin E. |authorlink=Martin E. Weaver |title=Historic Preservation Maintenance in the Netherlands: The Monumentenwacht |journal=[[Bulletin of the Association for Preservation Technology]] |volume=18 |issue=18 |date=1986 |pages=10-11 |doi=10.2307/1494114 |jstor=1494114}} A special kind of preservation that takes place in the Netherlands is the preservation of maritime heritage. Maritime trade was the Dutch specialty which shaped much of their culture and as a country that is 50% under sea level the Dutch history is closely intertwined with water.{{cite book|url=https://doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4020-4200-3_24|title=Flood Risk Management in Europe|first1=L.M.|last1=Bouwer|first2=P.|last2=Vellinga|date=20 October 2018|publisher=Springer Netherlands|pages=469–484|doi=10.1007/978-1-4020-4200-3_24}} There are maritime museums in both Amsterdam and Rotterdam that tell the story of the Dutch maritime heritage, but there is not much legal documentation on how to preserve it. For example, according to Sarah Dromgoole, https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/law/people/sarah.dromgoole shipwrecks from [[Dutch East India Company|The Dutch East India Company]] are found all around the world, which are still property of the Netherlands, but the Dutch government rarely takes responsibility for this property that is found outside of their territory.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.kr/books?id=nuSwCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169&dq=monumentenwet+1961&source=bl&ots=E4JlsRABjN&sig=wZoBBeGGK6nlqU1VABsCB6PPbfY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjrruD1h67XAhWEl5QKHZP_CjsQ6AEITTAG#v=onepage&q=monumentenwet%201961&f=false|title=The Protection of the Underwater Cultural Heritage: National Perspectives in Light of the UNESCO Convention 2001 - Second Edition|last=Dromgoole|first=Sarah|date=2006-06-30|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789047410454|language=en}} === Macedonia === In Macedonia, historic preservation falls under the overarching category of cultural heritage preservation according to the Law on Protection of Cultural Heritage (Закон за заштита на културното наследство). According to this law, which the Macedonian Parliament approved in March 2004, there are three types of cultural heritage: immovable, movable, and intangible. Historical preservation is represented by the protection of monuments and monumental entireties under immovable cultural heritage, and historical items under movable cultural heritage.[http://uzkn.gov.mk/dokumenti/Law%20on%20Cultural%20Heritage.pdf “Закон за заштита на културното наследство” (PDF)]. „Сл. Весник на Република Македонија“ бр.20/04. (in Macedonian). Retrieved 2017-11-08 Although this Law was the first nation-wide establishment of regulations for historic preservation since the Republic of Macedonia gained independence from Yugoslavia on September 8, 1991, several organizations throughout the 20th century have encompassed efforts of historic preservation. The “Central office for protection of cultural monuments and natural rarities of the Socialist Republic of Macedonia” has existed since 1949. In 1960, the Central Office was renamed to “National office for protection of cultural monuments”, and granted the status of an independent cultural institution, with authority to execute activities of historic preservation. After the establishment of the Law on Protection of Cultural Heritage in 2004, the Ministry of Culture once again renamed the office to “National center for conservation” and narrowed down its responsibilities to dealing solely with preservation of immovable cultural heritage.Jovcevska, Biljana. [http://archive.ftu.uklo.edu.mk/soopstenija/Magisterska%20BILJANA%20JOVCESKA.pdf “Abstract” (PDF)]. ftu.uklo,edu.mk (in Macedonian). Retrieved 2017-11-08. Other organizations which have contributed to the efforts of historic preservation are the Macedonian National Committee of ICOMOS and the NI Institute for Protection of Monuments of Culture and Museum-Ohrid. The [[International Council on Monuments and Sites|International Council on Monuments and Sites (ICOMOS)]] established their branch in Macedonia in 1995 through the initiative of 43 conservationists from Macedonia. The guiding principles of the Macedonian National Committee of ICOMOS are raising the national consciousness about the importance of historic and cultural heritage, decentralization of the discourse about heritage, and effective monitoring of the status of cultural and historic heritage in the country.[http://www.icomos.org.mk/AboutUs.aspx “ICOMOS Macedonia About Us”]. icomos.org.mk (in Macedonian). Retrieved 2017-11-08. The NI Institute for Protection of Monuments of Culture and Museum - Ohrid is the second oldest institutions for historical preservation established in 1952. In 1956 the Institute was granted authority to protect movable and immovable cultural and historic heritage in the Ohrid region. The Institute has since executed numerous efforts for historic preservation, most notably aiding the recognition of the city of Ohrid as a UNESCO site of cultural heritage in 1979.[http://muzejohrid.mk/istorija “Историја”]. НУ Завод за Заштита на Спомениците на Културата и Музеј - Охрид. (in Macedonian). Retrieved 2017-11-08. Today, the main authority for historic preservation is the Cultural Heritage Protection Office (Управа за заштита на културно наследство). The Office is an independent governmental organization under the Ministry of Culture, divided into three departments: #Identification, Protection and Use of Cultural Heritage #Prevention and Supervision #Documentation, International Cooperation and Administrative Affairs[http://unesdoc.unesco.org/images/0018/001881/188172eo.pdf "Cultural Heritage in South-East Europe: Macedonia (Former Yugoslav Republic of)" (PDF)]. "Cultural Heritage in South-East Europe" Series - N°, UNESCO. Retrieved 2017-11-08. === Israel === In Israel, there are currently two laws concerning historic preservation, [[Antiquities Law of the State of Israel of 1978|Antiquities Law of the State of Israel]] (1978){{cite web|url=http://main.knesset.gov.il/Activity/Legislation/Laws/Pages/LawPrimary.aspx?t=lawlaws&st=lawlaws&lawitemid=2000490|title=חוק מדינת ישראל|website=main.knesset.gov.il}} and Planning and Building Law (1965).{{cite web|url=http://mfa.gov.il/MFA/PressRoom/1998/Pages/Planning%20and%20Building%20Law-%201965.aspx|title=Summay of the law in English|publisher=}} Both laws were adapted from the British law that was implemented during the [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|British Mandate of Palestine]]. However, these laws are not comprehensive and limited in scope: the Antiquities Law only applies itself to buildings or artifacts dated before 1700 BC. So while efforts discovering and protecting anything older than 1700 BC are well protected, anything from later historical periods is not under the protection of this law. The Planning and Building Law discusses the overall management and regulation of land use in Israel. It has been through several changes and amendments specifically regarding preservation,{{cite web|url=http://main.knesset.gov.il/Activity/Legislation/Laws/Pages/LawPrimary.aspx?t=lawlaws&st=lawlaws&lawitemid=2000613|title=חוק מדינת ישראל|website=main.knesset.gov.il}} but over the years it hasn't been enforced and many historical sites were destroyed, as the state was prioritizing developmental and economic interests. During the 1960s, the issue of preservation was gaining public awareness, and as a response to the destruction of [[Herzliya Hebrew Gymnasium]] (one of the first educational institutions in Israel) in 1959, a wave of shock and anger led to extensive public debate.[[Yossi Klein Halevi|Klein Halevi, Yossi]] (2011). [http://www.kotar.co.il/KotarApp/Viewer.aspx?nBookID=96782691#6.2693.6.default האמרקניזציה של תל אביב]. In 1984, The Council for Conservation of Heritage Sites in Israel was established, at the recommendation of the Knesset and the Committee of Education. Its aims include locating remains of historic settlements, protect and conserve them as well as developing conservation principles that are specific to Israel’s historic situations and are aligned with international standards.{{cite web|url=http://eng.shimur.org/viewStaticPage.aspx?pageID=258|title=From the Council for Conservation of Heritage Sites|publisher=}} The council used to operate under the [[Society for the Protection of Nature in Israel]] but in 2008 registers as an independent non-profit. Today, it is the organization responsible for the most historical preservation endeavors as well as efforts to add amendments to existing laws to provide a comprehensive and effective framework for preservation in Israel.{{cite web|url=http://www.shimur.org/viewArticle.aspx?articleID=165|title=From the Council for Conservation of Heritage Sites: Historical context on the Council's work and outline of future plans [Hebrew]|publisher=}} A different, separate effort in preservation comes from the [[Israeli Defense Force]] (IDF). The IDF surveyed 94 military bases and found that about 80 of them include sites worth preserving, and for each of these bases there is a preservation plan.[http://www.mod.gov.il/building/engineering/Pages/preservation.aspx The Ministry of Defense statement regarding preservation within IDF bases [Hebrew]] The IDF is working towards maintaining these building as well as communicating their value to the soldiers in these bases. Buildings include [[Knights Templar]] sites, old military bases used by the British or German or buildings from the Ottoman period. ==National Register of Historic Places== {{Main|National Register of Historic Places}} [[File:HistoricPlacesNationalRegisterPlaque.JPG|thumb|[[National Register of Historic Places]] plaque]] ===National Historic Landmark=== {{main|National Historic Landmark}} ===Historic districts=== {{Main|Historic district (United States)}} A historic district in the [[United States]] is a group of buildings, properties, or sites that have been designated by one of several entities on different levels as historically or architecturally significant. Buildings, structures, objects and sites within a historic district are normally divided into two categories, [[Contributing property|contributing]] and non-contributing. Districts greatly vary in size, some having hundreds of structures while others have just a few. The [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. federal government]] designates historic districts through the [[U.S. Department of Interior]], under the auspices of the [[National Park Service]]. Federally designated historic districts are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.[http://www.cr.nps.gov/hps/workingonthepast/toolbox1.htm Federal, State and Local Historic Districts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061015030933/http://www.cr.nps.gov/hps/workingonthepast/toolbox1.htm |date=2006-10-15 }}, TOOLBOX, FAQ, National Park Service. Retrieved 19 February 2007 Historic districts allows rural areas to preserve their characters through historic preservation programs. These include "Main Street" programs that can be used to redevelop rural downtowns. Using historic preservation programs as an economic development tool for local governments in rural areas has enabled some of those areas to take advantage of their history and develop a tourism market that in turn provides funds for maintaining an economic stability that these areas would not have seen otherwise.[http://naldr.nal.usda.gov/NALWeb/Agricola_Link.asp?Accession=IND20529991 Stenberg, Peter L. (October 1995). "Historic Preservation as Part of Downtown Redevelopment."] ''Rural Development Perspectives'', Vol. 11, no.1, pp. 16-21. Washington, DC : Economic Research Service. Retrieved December 30, 2008.[http://www.nal.usda.gov/ric/ricpubs/preserve.html John, Patricia LaCaille (July 2008). "Historic Preservation Resources."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511165756/http://www.nal.usda.gov/ric/ricpubs/preserve.html |date=2008-05-11 }} Rural Information Center Publication Series no. 62. [[National Agricultural Library]]. Rural Information Center. Retrieved December 30, 2008. A similar concept exists in the United Kingdom: a [[Conservation area]] is designated in accordance with the [[Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990]] in order to protect a zone in which there are buildings of architectural or [[cultural heritage]] interest. ==National Parks== {{main|National Park}} In 1835, the English poet [[William Wordsworth]] described the [[Lake District]] as a "sort of national property, in which every man has a right and interest who has an eye to perceive and a heart to enjoy."{{cite book|last=Wordsworth|first=William|authorlink=William Wordsworth|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=idlAAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Guide+through+the+District+of+the+Lakes%E2%80%99&hl=en#v=onepage&q=sort%20of%20national%20property%20in%20which%20every%20man%20has%20a%20right%20and%20interest%20who%20has%20an%20eye%20to%20perceive%20and%20a%20heart%20to%20enjoy&f=false|title=A guide through the district of the lakes in the north of England with a description of the scenery, &c. for the use of tourists and residents|edition=5th|location=Kendal, England|publisher=Hudson and Nicholson|year=1835|page=88}} It was, however, the United States that led the world in the creation of [[United States National Park|National Parks]], areas of unspoiled natural wilderness, where the intrusion of civilization are intentionally minimal.{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} The department of the interior designated several areas of [[Morristown, New Jersey]] as the first historic park in the United States national park system. It became designated as the [[Morristown National Historical Park]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/morr/ |title=Morristown National Historical Park - Morristown National Historical Park |publisher=Nps.gov |date=2012-10-12 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} The community had permanent settlements that date to 1715, is termed the military capital of the American Revolution, and contains many designations of sites and locations. The park includes three major sites in Morristown. In the United Kingdom, [[James Bryce, 1st Viscount Bryce|James Bryce]] the [[ambassador]] to the US praised the system of National Parks and campaigned to have them introduced in Great Britain. Little came of it until mounting public pressure during the early 20th century from the [[Ramblers' Association]] and other groups led to the [[National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949]]. == UNESCO == According to UNESCO’s 1972 World Heritage Convention, landscapes and sites of outstanding universal value can be designated as [[World Heritage Site]]s. The World Heritage Convention encompasses historic preservation under the category of “cultural heritage”. According to Article 1 of the Convention, monuments, groups of buildings, and sites “which are of outstanding universal value from the point of view of history, art or science” are to be designated cultural heritage. A requirement of such designation is that the designating nation has appropriate legal, scientific, technical, administrative and financial measures in place to identify, protect, conserve, present, and rehabilitate world heritage sites. However, according to Article 6 of the Convention, while sovereignty of the State where the site is located is not to be compromised, the State acknowledges that protection of heritage sites is a duty of the entire international community.{{Cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/conventiontext/|title=Convention Concerning the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage|last=Centre|first=UNESCO World Heritage|website=whc.unesco.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-09}} The World Heritage convention’s counterpart, The World Heritage Committee,[http://whc.unesco.org/en/committee/ The World Heritage Committee] is the body responsible for the practical implementation of the Convention as well as managing and deciding how to use the World Heritage Fund. The Committee also gets to have the final say when determining whether a property will be included in the World Heritage List. The Committee meets once a year and includes representatives from 21 states that are part of the States Parties. Yearly reports are available to the public on the World Heritage website and include outlines of decisions made, outcomes, working documents and various reports.[http://whc.unesco.org/en/decisions/ All available reports of the Committee] == Potential challenges == Although preservation efforts can have benefits for the owners of historical buildings, such as tax cuts and subsidies, there are also drawbacks. One such drawback is that after a neighborhood has been designated to be historically preserved, there is less construction. On the long term this can affect the value of property and investment in housing, both in the neighborhood itself and the neighborhoods directly surrounding it.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nber.org.ccl.idm.oclc.org/papers/w20446.pdf)%20(http://readings.sipx.com/in-efa1d268-3446-11e4-b0d4-22000a890e29/c-a5bb0b99-34dc-11e7-8e82-22000b61898b/x-18c7cf2c-4b0a-11e7-8e82-22000b61898b.pdf?Expires=1510044499&Signature=OYOvpPRjsvsdxGk8mFJuuvpqTmeZ2aWRa5PyPPJ3HEyNSDr36kObybQETDowEcAnOP10WnB82VVejixBL~YiqGuKe6ZJ-fFchJ2tcVcrt4A7QNKhALWi1jE0z2XkqC8tZxb6picEAwMJ3MhUCtEHoA8-kajtxQQaA9QgAjfzX~4_&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIVBE35QX7A7QYJEA|title=Preserving History or Hindering Growth? The Heterogeneous Effects of Historic Districts on Local Housing Markets in New York City|last=Been, Gould Ellen, Gedal, Glaeser, & McCabe|first=Vicki, Ingrid, Michael, Edward, Brian J.|date=|website=|access-date=}} A second concern that has been raised is that buildings that need to be historically preserved are sometimes still inhabited. In some cases their inability to make changes to the building can lead to dangerous or unhealthy situations for residents.Li, C. (2012). The politics and heritage of race and space in San Francisco’s Chinatown. In D. F. Ruggles (Ed.), ''On location'' (pp. 37–59). New York, NY: Springer. It is not true that nothing could be changed or renovated, but the owner of the building would need to ask permission at the appropriate preservation society, slowing the process down severely. The exact policies are country dependent.Barrett, J. (2016). Getting Away From “No”: Straight Talk to Local Advocates. ''Forum Journal'' 30(2), 46-49. National Trust for Historic Preservation. Retrieved November 7, 2017, from Project MUSE database. ==Influential people== * [[Eugène Viollet-le-Duc]] (1814-1879): French architect who restored Gothic buildings and believed that restoration could improve on the past. * [[Ann Pamela Cunningham]] (1816–1875): influential in saving [[Mount Vernon (plantation)]] from demolition and founding the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association, one of the first preservation organizations in the United States (est. 1854).[http://www.nwhm.org/Education/biography_apcunningham.html "Biography of Ann Pamela Cunningham"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410043142/http://www.nwhm.org/Education/biography_apcunningham.html |date=2010-04-10 }} ''National Women's History Museum.'' Retrieved 21 April 2010. * [[John Ruskin]] (1819-1900): English art critic who established the basic theory of preservation (retention of status quo). * [[Augustus Pitt Rivers]] (1827–1900): Britain's first Inspector of Ancient Monuments. * [[John Lubbock, 1st Baron Avebury|John Lubbock]] (1834-1913): campaigned for legal protection for ancient monuments and saved [[Avebury]] from destruction at the hand of its private owners. * [[William Morris]] (1834-1896): English designer and writer who founded the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]]. * [[Camillo Boito]] (1836-1914): Italian architect who tried to reconcile the conflicting views of Viollet-le-Duc and Ruskin, inspiring modern legislation on restoration in several countries * [[Victor de Stuers]] (1843-1916): Dutch art historian, lawyer, civil servant and politician. First legal secretary at the Ministry of Home Affairs as chief of the brand new Department of Arts and Sciences. * [[George Curzon, 1st Marquess Curzon of Kedleston|George Curzon]] (1859-1925): British [[Viceroy of India]] who preserved [[Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire]] and was an influential sponsor of the [[Ancient Monuments Consolidation and Amendment Act 1913]]. * [[William Sumner Appleton]] (1874-1947): Founder of the Society for the Preservation of New England Antiquities (now Historic New England) in 1910, and widely considered as the U.S.'s first professional preservationist. * [[Charles E. Peterson]] (1906–2004): considered to be the "founding father" of historic preservation in the United States. * [[James Marston Fitch]] (1909-2000): educator, author, critic and design practitioner made a major contribution to the philosophical basis of the modern preservation movement and trained and inspired generations of preservationists. * William J. Murtagh: first Keeper of the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in the United States and significant contributor to the literature of the discipline.[http://www.aia.org/nwsltr_hrc.cfm?pagename=hrc_a_20060317_murtaugh] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070807010424/http://www.aia.org/nwsltr_hrc.cfm?pagename=hrc_a_20060317_murtaugh |date=August 7, 2007 }} * Lee H. Nelson: worked for Charles E. Peterson at the National Park Service's [[Historic American Buildings Survey]] and helped to formulate national policies on historic preservation. * [[Walter Muir Whitehill]]: Chairman of the Whitehill Report in the late 1960s, which established the first guidelines for higher education historic preservation programs. * [[Richard Nickel]]: American preservationist who saved architectural elements from [[Louis Sullivan]] buildings. ==Careers== Although volunteers continue to play a large role in historic preservation activities, the field has seen an increased level of professionalization. Today, there are many career options in historic preservation in the public, non-profit and private sectors. Institutes of secondary education (universities, colleges, etc.) in the United States offer both certificate and degree ([[Associate in Applied Science|A.A.S]], [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]], [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|B.F.A.]], [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]], [[Master of Arts|M.A.]], [[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]], [[Masters of Design Studies|M.D.S]], [[Master of Historic Preservation|M.H.P.]], [[Master of Science|M.S.]], and [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) programs in historic preservation. Some pupils—at schools with such programmes available—choose to enroll in "joint degree" programs, earning a degree in historic preservation along with one in another, related subject, often an [[Master of Architecture|MArch]], [[Master of Urban Planning|MUP]] or [[Juris Doctor|JD]] degree. Possible career fields include: ;Architectural conservator: Focus specifically on the physical conservation of building materials. ;Architectural historian/historian: Primarily researches and writes statements expressing the historical significance of sites. ;Historic preservation planner: Most are employed by local, county, state or federal government planning agencies to administer tax abatement programs, ensure compliance with local ordinances and state and Federal legislation, and conduct design reviews to ensure that proposed projects will not harm historic and archaeological resources. At the state level, they are known as a [[State Historic Preservation Officer]] while at other levels of government they may be known as a Federal or Tribal Historic Preservation Officer. Some may also serve as consultants to local governments, conducting [[Town and Country Planning Act 1990|Section 106]] reviews in accordance with the [[National Historic Preservation Act of 1966]]. ;Preservation architect: Design and develop architectural conservation plans and work specifications in consultation with Engineers, Historians and Planners, ensuring compliance with local design guidelines to protect sensitive historic building fabric. Most are employed by private architecture firms though some find work with government agencies. ;Preservation craftsperson/[[Traditional trades|traditional trades practitioner]]: Employs knowledge of traditional building techniques and contemporary conservation technologies to complete the conservation, repair or restoration of historic buildings. ;Preservation engineer: Work with Architects to devise conservation solutions of a structural or material -specific nature. Most are employed by private architecture and/or engineering firms. ;[[Public historian]]/[[Heritage interpretation|resource interpreters]]: Most are employed by government agencies and private foundations to interpret the significance of historic resources for the general public. ;[[Historic site|Historic site administrator]] ;Non-profit sector careers: Engage in a variety of activities concerned with historic preservation advocacy, easements, and private foundations at the local, regional, statewide, or national levels. ===Professional organisations=== * [[American Institute for Important for its introduction of restoration theory. {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Heritage preservation}} * [http://www.usicomos.org/preservation An Overview of Preservation in the United States] (US/ICOMOS) * [http://www.nps.gov/history/archeology/tools/laws/index.htm Archeology Laws: A Guide for Professionals (National Park Service)] * [http://www.historicplaces.ca/nor-sta/norm-stan_e.aspx Standards and Guidelines for the Conservation of Historic Places in Canada] * [http://www.nps.gov/history/preservation.htm Standards and Guidelines for Preservation in the United States] {{Lists of World Heritage Sites}} {{Registered Historic Places}} {{Conservation-Restoration}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Historic Preservation}} [[Category:Historic preservation| ]] [[Category:Architectural history]] [[Category:Cultural heritage]] [[Category:Museology]] [[Category:Conservation and restoration]] [[fr:Monument historique (Espagne)]]

{{Distinguish | History of anthropology}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{Anthropology}} '''Historical anthropology''' is a [[historiographical]] movement which applies methodologies and objectives from [[Social Anthropology|Social]] and [[Cultural Anthropology]] to the study of historical societies.<ref>Elizabeth A. Ten Dyke, 'Anthropology, Historical' in Encyclopedia of Historians and Historical Writing, ed. by Kelly Boyd (Chicago: Fitzroy Dearborn, 1999), pp. 37--40 (p. 37).</ref> Like most such movements, it is understood in different ways by different scholars, and to some may be synonymous with the [[history of mentalities]], [[cultural history]], [[ethnohistory]], [[microhistory]], [[People's history|history from below]] or ''[[Alltagsgeschichte]]''. Anthropologists whose work has been particularly inspirational to historical anthropology include [[Emile Durkheim]], [[Clifford Geertz]], [[Arnold van Gennep]], [[Jack Goody]], [[Lucien Lévy-Bruhl]], [[Marcel Mauss]] and [[Victor Turner]].<ref name="autogenerated37">Elizabeth A. Ten Dyke, 'Anthropology, Historical' in Encyclopedia of Historians and Historical Writing, ed. by Kelly Boyd (Chicago: Fitzroy Dearborn, 1999), pp. 37--40 (p. 38).</ref>
[[Peter Burke (historian)|Peter Burke]] has contrasted historical anthropology with [[Social History]], finding that historical anthropology tends to focus on qualitative rather than quantitative data, smaller communities, and symbolic aspects of culture.<ref name="autogenerated37"/> Thus it reflects a turn away, in the 1960s, in [[Marxist historiography]] from 'the orthodox Marxist approach to human behaviour in which actors are seen as motivated in the first instance by economics, and only secondarily by culture or ideology', in the work of historians such as [[E. P. Thompson]].<ref name="autogenerated37"/>
Historical anthropology was rooted in the [[Annales School]], associated with a succession of major historians such as [[Fernand Braudel]], [[Jacques Le Goff]], [[Emmanuel Le Roy Ladurie]] and [[Pierre Nora]], along with researchers from elsewhere on the Continent such as [[Carlo Ginzburg]]. The label ''historical anthropology'' has been actively promoted by some recent Annales School historians, such as [[Jean-Claude Schmitt]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jean-Claude Schmitt |url=https://cem.revues.org/8862 |title=Anthropologie historique |publisher=Cem.revues.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://acrh.revues.org/1926 |title=L’anthropologie historique de l’Occident médiéval. Un parcours |publisher=Acrh.revues.org |date= |accessdate=2015-08-17}}</ref> Established in 1929 by [[Marc Bloch]] and [[Lucien Febvre]], the review [[Annales. Histoire, Sciences sociales]] is still among the most influential French publications for research in historical anthropology.
Historical anthropology has been open to similar criticisms to anthropology: 'as [[Bernard Cohn (anthropologist)|Bernard Cohn]] and [[John Comaroff|John]] and [[Jean Comaroff]] have observed, studies in which societies were represented in this way were often partial, biased, and unwitting handmaidens to the domination of non-Western peoples by Europeans and Americans'.<ref name="autogenerated37"/> But since the Second World War, increasingly reflexive approaches have led to sophisticated developments of the field, and the banner of 'historical anthropology' has often attracted Anglo-American historians in ways that the Annales School did not: key figures have been [[Sidney Mintz]], [[Jay O'Brien (anthropologist)|Jay O'Brien]], [[William Roseberry]], [[Marshall Sahlins]], [[Jane Schneider]], [[Peter Schneider (historian)|Peter Schneider]], [[Eric Wolf]], [[Peter Burke (historian)|Peter Burke]], and people from elsewhere in the world such as [[Aaron Gurevich]].
==See also== *[[Cultural anthropology]] *[[Historiography]] *[[Rural history]] *[[Nouvelle histoire]] *[[Social history]] *[[Marxist historiography]]

[[File:Comissió avaluadora de la consulta d'Arenys de Munt.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Jordi Bilbeny]] (far left) at the count of the [[Catalan independence referendums, 2009–11|2009 independence referendum]] in [[Arenys de Munt]]]] The '''Institut Nova Història''' (INH) is a [[Catalonia|Catalan]] cultural [[Foundation (nonprofit)|foundation]] with headquarters in [[Barcelona]]. Its members, of which the most prominent is the Catalan nationalist writer [[Jordi Bilbeny]], hold that history has been systematically manipulated by the Spanish (or "Castilian") state since the 15th century to eliminate the Catalan contribution to world history. They claim that major historical figures, including [[Christopher Columbus]], [[Erasmus]], [[Miguel de Cervantes]], [[William Shakespeare]], [[Leonardo da Vinci]], [[Teresa of Ávila|Saint Teresa of Ávila]] and others were Catalan. The institute's work has been criticised as [[pseudohistory]].
The institute promotes research, study and dissemination of ideas about Catalan influence on history through publications, conferences and symposia, in particular the annual "Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America" in [[Arenys de Munt]]. It is funded by the [[Generalitat de Catalunya|Catalan autonomous government]], and has received support from [[Catalan nationalism|Catalan nationalist]] politicians.
== History == [[File:Víctor Cucurull 2011 (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Víctor Cucurull in 2011]] The INH was created in 2007 following a split in the Foundation of Historical Studies of Catalonia.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mas|first=Andreu|title =Colom era català, barceloní, i d'una nissaga noble|url=http://www.codic.cat/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/codic-cat-2009-11-03-El-Punt-Noticia-Colom-era-Catala-Barceloni-i-d-una-nissaga-noble-98608.pdf|work=El Punt|date =3 November 2009|language = Catalan}}</ref> The principal researcher of the INH is [[Jordi Bilbeny]], a member of the "Arenysian Movement for Self-Determination", a local independentist movement, and of the Arenys de Munt's [[Popular Unity Candidacy]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2009/11/ximenis-i-bilbeny-analitzen-les-consultes-en-una-xerrada-a-besalu-aquest-divendres-8026|title= imenis i Bilbeny analitzen les consultes en una xerrada a Besalú aquest divendres|work=Llibertat.cat|date=3 November 2009|language=Catalan|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140804160245/http://www.llibertat.cat/2009/11/ximenis-i-bilbeny-analitzen-les-consultes-en-una-xerrada-a-besalu-aquest-divendres-8026|archive-date=4 August 2014}}</ref> who launched the "Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America" in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.elpuntavui.cat/noticia/article/5-cultura/19-cultura/331617-error-intencionat.html|title=Error intencionat? Un simposi d'historiadors a Arenys de Mar debatrà el possible origen català de Colom i per què es va negar|work=El Punt Avui|date=16 November 2010|language=Catalan}}</ref> From its inception, the INH has undertaken the study and dissemination of the Catalan background and/or culture of [[Christopher Columbus]], [[Miguel de Cervantes]], ''[[Lazarillo de Tormes]]'', all topics put forward by Bilbeny.<ref name=DB091130>{{cite news|last=Marí|first=Francesca|title=Castella no té història universal|work=dBalears|date=30 November 2009 |language = Catalan|url=http://dbalears.cat/actualitat/cultura/castella-no-te-historia-universal.html}}</ref> The president of the Institute is Albert Codinas,<ref name=Segura>{{cite news |last=Segura |first=Cristián |date= 26 November 2014 |title=Were Columbus, Cervantes and Leonardo da Vinci really Catalan? |url= https://elpais.com/elpais/2014/11/25/inenglish/1416926983_487701.html|work=El País |location=Madrid |access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> vice president of the {{lang|ca|Fundació Catalunya Estat}}, secretary of the {{lang|ca|Associació Catalunya 2014}}, and co-founder of the Platform for the Right to Decide.<ref>{{cite web|last=Marfull i Pujadas|first=Andreu|title=Entrevista a l'Albert Codinas a la revista LA FADA de Sarrià|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Entrevista-a-l’Albert-Codinas-a-la-revista-LA-FADA-de-Sarria|website=Institut Nova Història|date=26 August 2014|language = Catalan|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141122175709/http://www.inh.cat/articles/Entrevista-a-l%E2%80%99Albert-Codinas-a-la-revista-LA-FADA-de-Sarria|archive-date =22 November 2014}}</ref> Víctor Cucurull, another researcher,<ref>{{cite news|last=Alonso de la Torre|first= J. R.|title=Pizarro era de Cataluña|url=http://www.hoy.es/extremadura/201409/03/pizarro-cataluna-20140903001236-v.html|work=hoy.es| date=3 September 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref> is president of the {{lang|ca|Fundació Societat i Cultura}},<ref>{{cite web|title=Conferència amb Víctor Cucurull|url=http://www.vilafrancaxindependencia.cat/index.php/7-noticies/36-conferencia-amb-victor-cucurull |website=ANC Vilafranca per la Independència|date=13 February 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> and a member of the national secretariat of the [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Segura|first=Cristian |title=Complot històric contra Catalunya|url=http://cat.elpais.com/cat/2014/11/23/cultura/1416763119_988379.html|work=El País| date=23 November 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref>
The INH has supported and organized, together with the municipality of [[Arenys de Munt]], the ''Simposis sobre la descoberta catalana d'Amèrica'' (Symposium on the Catalan Discovery of America),<ref name=Segura/> held since 2001, where speakers present research on the [[Discovery of the Americas]] by the Catalans.<ref name=INH090501>{{cite web|last=Bassa|first=David|title=Manifest a favor del Simposi d'Arenys de Munt|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Manifest-a-favor-del-Simposi-d-Arenys-de-Munt |website= Institut Nova Història|date=1 May 2009|language=Catalan|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20140804161707/http://www.inh.cat/articles/Manifest-a-favor-del-Simposi-d-Arenys-de-Munt|archive-date=4 August 2014}}</ref> In 2013, the Institute organized the first Universitat Nova Història in [[Pla de l'Estany]], under the sponsorship of the [[Province of Girona|Provincial Council of Girona]], the municipality of [[Arenys de Mar]], Cercle Català de Negocis (Catalan Business Circle), asamblea.cat, the Regional Council of [[Pla de l'Estany]] and Fundació Catalunya Estat.<ref name=llib>{{cite news| title = Primera Universitat Nova Història durant l'agost|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/07/primera-universitat-nova-historia-durant-l-agost-a-crespia-22225 |work=llibertat.cat |date =3 July 2013|language = Catalan| archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20130925053315/http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/07/primera-universitat-nova-historia-durant-l-agost-a-crespia-22225|archive-date=25 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = 1a Universitat Nova Història, de l'1 al 4 d'agost a Crespià|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/1a-Universitat-Nova-Historia,-de-l%271-al-4-d%27agost-a-Crespia|website= Institut Nova Història|date=2 July 2013|language=Catalan}}</ref>
== Theories == [[File:Barcelona - Plaça Portal de la Pau - View West on Columbus Statue 1888.jpg|thumb|120px|Statue of [[Christopher Columbus]] in Barcelona]] [[File:Mona Lisa, by Leonardo da Vinci, from C2RMF retouched.jpg|thumb|120px|The [[Mona Lisa]], by [[Leonardo da Vinci]]]] The INH considers that the history of Catalonia has been manipulated and distorted since the end of the 15th century to favour the construct of a centralised Spanish ("Castilian") state. By minimising the role of Catalonia—or the [[Crown of Aragon]]—in Spanish collective history through falsification, concealment and censorship or "appropriation" of certain historical episodes, the prevalence of Castilian ideology is established.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pere Forès i Malleu|first=Pere|title = Esborrant la traça catalana|magazine=Presència|location=Barcelona|number=2021|date=19 November 2010|pages=28–31|id= GI-143-1965}}</ref> Among its claims are: *That [[Christopher Columbus]], who discovered the Americas, was a Catalan;<ref name=Garín/><ref name=Crameri>{{cite journal|last=Crameri|first=Kathryn|date=2012|title=History Written by the Losers: History, Memory, Myth and Independence in Twenty-First Century Catalonia. |url=https://conservancy.umn.edu/bitstream/handle/11299/184381/hiol_11_02_crameri_history_written_by_the_losers.pdf?sequence=1|journal=Hispanic Issues on Line| number=11|page= 39 |issn=1931-8006 |publisher=University of Minnesota|location=Minnesota|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> that his real name was Joan Colom i Bertran; that he was "a Catalan noble that fought against [[Ferdinand II of Aragon|Ferdinand II]] in the [[Catalan Civil War]] of 1462-1472 and so needed to change his identity in order to avoid persecution by royalist forces"; and that he sailed from the port of [[Pals]] rather than from [[Palos de Moguer]].<ref name=Rodríguez/> According to INH, [[Erasmus]] of Rotterdam was actually named Ferran, and was the second son of this Joan Colom i Bertran (Columbus).<ref name=EC140630>{{cite news |last=Fernández|first=Antonio|title=Las teorías independentistas que convierten en catalanes a personajes históricos|url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2014-06-30/las-teorias-independentistas-que-convierten-en-catalanes-a-personajes-historicos_153935/|work=El Confidencial|date=30 June 2014| language = Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last= Mayolas|first=Pep|title=Pep Mayolas: «La meva hipòtesi és que Erasme era català i fill d’En Colom»|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Pep-Mayolas:-La-meva-hipotesi-es-que-Erasme-era-catala-i-fill-d|accessdate=16 November 2018|website=Intitut Nova Història|date=21 April 2014|language=catalán}}</ref> *That [[Hernán Cortés]] was actually Ferran Cortès, a Catalan noble;<ref name=Segura/><ref>{{cite news|title=Hernán Cortés también era catalán y se llamaba Ferran Cortès|url=http://www.elmanifiesto.com/articulos.asp?idarticulo=4689 |work=elmanifiesto.com|date=29 April 2014|language = Spanish}}</ref> [[Francisco Pizarro]] was Francesc Pinós De So i Carròs; [[Diego de Almagro]]'s real name was Jaume d'Aragó-Dalmau;<ref>{{cite web|last=Mayolas|first=Pep|title=Francisco Pizarro i Diego de Almagro, dos conquistadors de nissaga reial catalana|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Francisco-Pizarro-i-Diego-de-Almagro,-dos-conquistadors-de-nissaga-reial-catalana|website=Institut Nova Història|date=17 April 2014| language=Catalan}}</ref> [[Amerigo Vespucci]]'s last name was a distortion of the surname "Despuig", and his voyage to the new world was made in the name of the "King of Catalonia".<ref name=Segura/><ref name=EC140630/><ref>{{cite web|author=Jordi Bilbeny|title=Américo Vespuche era un Despuig. Primera part de l'estudi d'en Jordi Bilbeny|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Americo-Vespuche-era-un-Despuig.-Primera-part-de-l%27estudi-d%27en-Jordi-Bilbeny|website= Institut Nova Història|date=22 February 2012|language=Catalan}}</ref> Thus, the feat of discovery and conquest was accomplished entirely by Catalans, the only people who sailed to the Americas before 1518.<ref name=DB091130/> *That [[Miguel de Cervantes]] was a Catalan,<ref name=Garín/><ref name=Crameri/> whose real name was Joan Miquel Servent, and who was a native of [[Xixona]];<ref>{{cite web |last=Esquivel|first= Francisco|title=Cervantes, català|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Cervantes,-catala- |website=Institut Nova Història|date=16 October 2012|language=Catalan}}</ref> that ''[[Don Quixote]]'' was a faulty translation of the original work in Catalan, ''El Quixot'', which was destroyed by the Castilians,<ref>{{cite web|last=Villarrodà|first= Jordi|title=El Quixot és la traducció d’una obra catalana, d’en Joan Miquel Servent|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/%27El-Quixot-es-la-traduccio-d |website= Institut Nova Història | date =30 January 2013|language = Catalan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Riera|first=José|title=El Quixot és una mala traducció de l'original en català|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/El-Quixot-es-una-mala-traduccio-de-l%27original-en-catala|website=Institut Nova Història|date=1 March 2010|language=Catalan}}</ref> and "passed off as Castilian".<ref name=Segura/> In fact, according to Miquel Izquierdo i Perán from INH, Servent had to flee Spain and once in England, published his works under the pseudonym “[[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]]”, thereby making Servent, Cervantes and Shakespeare one and the same person.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bernat Puigtobella|first=Bernat |title=Shakespeare era català|url=http://www.nuvol.com/opinio/shakespeare-era-catala/|work=Punt de Llibre|language=catalán|date=22 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Nerín|first=Gustau|title=Van ser Cervantes i Shakespeare la mateixa persona?|url=http://www.elnacional.cat/ca/cultura-idees-arts/cervantes-shakespeare-miquel-izquierdo_101410_102.html|work=El Nacional.cat|language=ES|date=7 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fernández|first=Laura|title=Un libro sostiene que Cervantes y Shakespeare eran la misma persona: un catalán|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cataluna/2016/04/13/570e97d6ca4741d7718b461d.html|work=El Mundo|language=ES|date=13 April 2016}}</ref> *That [[Leonardo da Vinci]] was Catalan, born in a town near Montserrat, such as [[Manresa]], [[Vic]] or [[La Garriga]];<ref name=Mendo>{{cite news| last=Mendo|first=A.|title=Colón y Da Vinci son catalanes, según un grupo de historiadores nacionalistas|url=http://www.antena3.com/noticias/espana/colon-vinci-son-catalanes-segun-grupo-historiadores-nacionalistas_2014070800252.html|work=Antena 3|date=8 July 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Mirror>{{cite web|first=Jose Luis|last=Espejo|title=Leonardo, Montserrat i el secret de la Gioconda|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Leonardo,-Montserrat-i-el-secret-de-la-Gioconda |website= Institut Nova Història|date=5 May 2009|language=Catalan}}</ref><ref name=Segura/><ref name="El Punt">{{cite web|title=Jordi Bilbeny «Desmuntant Leonardo» a El Punt Avui TV|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Jordi-Bilbeny-Desmuntant-Leonardo-a-El-Punt-Avui-TV |website=Institut Nova Història|date=4 August 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> that [[Mona Lisa]] was actually [[Isabella of Aragon, Duchess of Milan|Isabella of Aragon]]; that the mountains depicted at the bottom of the portrait were the [[Montserrat (mountain)|Montserrat mountain range]]; and that Da Vinci's coat of arms was very similar to that of the "Catalan Royal House".<ref name=Segura/> These ideas were put forward in a 2014 documentary, ''Desmutant Leonardo ''(Deconstructing Leonardo), on {{lang|ca|El Punt Avui TV}}.<ref name="Cat Radio">{{cite web|title = Parlem de 'Desmuntant Leonardo' a Catalunya Ràdio|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Parlem-de-%27Desmuntant-Leonardo%27-a-Catalunya-Radio|website = Institut Nova Història|date=July 28, 2014|language=Catalan}}; Interview with Jordi Bilbeny at [[Catalunya Ràdio]].</ref> *That the original versions of ''[[La Celestina]]'' and ''[[Lazarillo de Tormes]]''—the latter having been written by Joan Timoneda—were in Catalan and were destroyed after having been translated into Castilian.<ref name=EC140630/> *That [[Teresa of Ávila|Saint Teresa of Ávila]] was actually Teressa Enrìques de Cardona, abbess at the [[Monastery of Pedralbes]] for thirty years.<ref name=ABC140614/><ref> {{cite news|first=José Ángel|last=Montañés| title = Sin rastro de Santa Teresa en el monasterio de Pedralbes|url=http://ccaa.elpais.com/ccaa/2014/12/24/catalunya/1419436345_910279.html|work= El País| language = Spanish|date=24 December 2014}}</ref> *That the first university founded in the Iberian Peninsula was the [[University of Barcelona]], rather than the universities of [[University of Salamanca|Salamanca]] and [[University of Palencia|Palencia]].<ref>{{cite news|url = http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2016-12-26/teorias-independentistas-universidad-de-barcelona-mas-antigua-que-salamanca_1309166/|title=La última teoría independentista: Barcelona ya tenía universidad antes que Salamanca|work=El Confidencial|date=26 December 2016|last=Fernández|first=Antonio|language=Spanish }}</ref> *That the design of the [[Flag of the United States|flag of the United States of America]] was inspired by the Catalan [[senyera]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Jordi|last=Bilbeny|title=Sobre l'origen de la bandera dels Estats Units d'Amèrica|url=http://www.inh.cat/articles/Sobre-l'origen-de-la-bandera-dels-Estats-Units-d'America|website=Institut Nova Història|language=Catalan|date=5 December 2010}}</ref>
==Support from Catalan nationalists== The INH is funded by the Catalan autonomous government.<ref name=Garín>{{cite book|last =Garín|first= Alberto|chapter=A Non-Manifesto of Liberal History|year=2018|editors= Douma, Michael J. and Magness, Phillip W.|title=What is Classical Liberal History|publisher= Lexington Books|location=Lanham, Md.|isbn=9781498536103|pages=211–212|url= https://books.google.co.ve/books?id=V19CDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA211&lpg#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> It has collaborated with the separatist [[Assemblea Nacional Catalana|Catalan National Assembly]] in organising conferences on the history of Catalonia.<ref name=ABC140614>{{cite news|last=Guil|first= Janot|title=La Asamblea Nacional Catalana se apropia también de Santa Teresa de Jesús|url=http://www.abc.es/espana/20140611/abci-asamblea-nacional-catalana-apropia-201406102146.html | work=ABC|date=11 June 2014|language=SP}}</ref> In 2013 it was one of the recipients of the {{lang|ca|Premi Nacional President Lluís Companys}} (President Lluís Companys National Awards) by the [[Sants-Montjuïc]] branch of [[Esquerra Republicana de Catalunya]].<ref>{{cite news| title = L'Institut Nova Història serà guardonat amb el Premi Nacional President Lluís Companys|url=http://www.llibertat.cat/2013/10/l-institut-nova-historia-sera-guardonat-amb-el-premi-nacional-president-lluis-companys-23431 | work = llibertat.cat | date = 16 October 2013 | language = Catalan}}</ref> In 2012 the former president of the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]], [[Jordi Pujol]], wrote to Bilbeny congratulating him on his book ''Discovery and Catalan conquest of America. A history rewritten by the Castilians'', noting that the books published by the INH "are very convincing", while in 2014, the former vice-president of the Generalitat de Catalunya, [[Josep Lluís Carod-Rovira]], participated at the reissue of Bilbeny's ''Brief account of the destruction of history'', where he spoke in praise of the book.<ref name=EC140804>{{cite news|last=Fernández|first=A.|title=Jordi Pujol y Carod se suman a la teoría de que Colón y los Pinzón eran catalanes|url=http://www.elconfidencial.com/espana/cataluna/2014-07-03/jordi-pujol-y-carod-se-suman-a-la-teoria-de-que-colon-y-los-pinzon-eran-catalanes_155815/|work=El Confidencial|date=3 July 2014|language = Spanish}}</ref>
The 2015 INH symposium in [[Arenys de Munt]], under the title "The Catalan Discovery of America", was financed by the councils of Arenys de Munt and [[Arenys de Mar]], together with associations such as the {{lang|ca|Ateneu Independentista}} of Arenys de Munt. [[Muriel Casals i Couturier|Muriel Casals]], representative of the separatist coalition [[Junts pel Sí]], gave the closing speech entitled "From the erased past to political independence".<ref>{{cite news|last=Ruiz Coll|first=M.A.|title=ERC reúne a 40 historiadores con dinero público para demostrar que Da Vinci, Marco Polo, Colón y Cervantes eran catalanes|url=https://okdiario.com/espana/cataluna/2015/11/25/erc-reune-a-40-historiadores-con-dinero-publico-para-demostrar-que-da-vinci-marco-polo-colon-y-cervantes-eran-catalanes-28378|work=ok diario| language=Spanish|date=25 November 2015}}</ref>
INH members have given talks on their theories in the main Catalan government-owned television and radio channels such as [[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]] and [[Catalunya Ràdio]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ccma.cat/tv3/alacarta/el-documental/desmuntant-leonardo/video/5561885/|title=Desmuntant Leonardo|author=[[TV3 (Catalonia)|TV3]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Prkiy0K0Cuk|publisher=youtube|title=Entrevista Mònica Terribas: Bilbeny/Grau (1/4) histocat.cat}}</ref><ref name="El Punt"/><ref name="Cat Radio"/>
==Criticism== The INH has been described by one academic as "a group of Catalan self-styled scholars trying to prove and promote the idea that, throughout History, a massive conspiracy by the Crown of Castille, the Inquisition, and any institution that may be related to Castille, has been orchestrated against the nation of Catalonia to deprive it of its History and cultural identity in order to promote Castile".<ref name=Rodríguez>{{cite journal |last=Rodríguez López-Abadía |first=Arturo |date=2014 |title=The origins of Christopher Columbus, a never-ending controversy |url=https://www.academia.edu/9952462/The_origins_of_Christopher_Columbus_a_never-ending_controversy |journal=Revista Internacional Digilec|volume=Vol. 1|number=1|pages=1 to 10 |issn=2386-6691|access-date=9 April 2018}}</ref> It was criticised in the Catalan parliament by the opposition party [[Citizens (Spanish political party)|Ciudadanos]] spokeswoman, Carina Mejías, who described its theories as "ridiculous".<ref>{{cite news|last=Sallés|first=Quico|title = C's: «És ridícul dir que Cristòfol Colom és català»|url=http://www.naciodigital.cat/noticia/67614/es/ridicul/dir/cristofol/colom/catala|work= NacióDigital.cat|date =22 April 2014|language=Catalan}}</ref> Javier Barraycoa, vice-chancellor of the [[Abat Oliba CEU University]], former secretary of the {{ill|Carlist Traditionalist Communion|ca|Comunió Tradicionalista Carlista}} in Catalonia,<ref>{{cite web|title= Directorio General de la Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista|url=http://www.carlistas.es/descargas/organigrama.pdf|website=Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista| language=Spanish|date=January 2013}}</ref> and member of the anti-Catalanist organisation [[Somatemps]], said that the INH "has absolutely no recognition in the academic world" and that its members "have not been invited to any serious congress because it is impossible for them to defend these things."<ref>{{cite news|last=Moreno|first=Rosalina|title=Barraycoa: ‘Cataluña vive un delirio colectivo’|url=http://www.gaceta.es/noticias/cataluna-vive-delirio-colectivo-10072014-1128|work=La Gaceta |date=10 July 2014|language=Spanish}}</ref>
